subject: a modern manual (beta!)
msgSnippet: I just uploaded a project I have worked on, bits and pieces, for a little while: an updated QS manual.  I do not really want to re-write Read s work, but
messageBody:
I just uploaded a project I have worked on, bits and pieces, for a
little while: an updated QS manual. I do not really want to re-write
Read's work, but rather take that scanned work to make it a bit
cleaner, smaller, and searchable. The only real editorial liberty I
have taken so far is changing all of the references to "No. 5/25" etc.
and replacing them with actual Quickscript characters, inline.

The first version used the jerome font, and I often would reformat a
paragraph and it would lose the information about which font was to be
displayed: a real pain. So yesterday I converted Kingsley, which
looks very similar to the style in the original manual, to use the
conscript unicode block (as I had with Jeremy, once before). I
converted everything to the new encoding, and it worked pretty well.

However, the Kingsley font, and jerome before it, have some major
problems with kerning. The text I entered sometimes looked as though
there were spaces within the word, for example if a short letter
followed He or came before Pea or Bay. I decided to explore the font
editor I have been using a bit more
(http://fontforge.sourceforge.net/), and learned how to do pair
kerning... so I spent a long(!) time last night tuning the kerning on
all of the letter pairs, and came up with something that produces
(IMHO) some of the best computer-rendered quickscript so far.

I am not ready to release the font file, yet: but please take a quick
look at the file I just uploaded and it should display correctly (it
does for me, on a machine that doesn't have the font installed).
Other comments on the manual reproduction are also welcome.

oliver
